And they also include the following defaults file under`/etc/default/` (remove `.txt`):
[syncthing-relaysrv.txt](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/files/2281100/syncthing-relaysrv.txt)

issue.title: syncthing-discosrv and syncthing-relaysrv do not include systemd files
issue.body: The `syncthing-discosrv` and `syncthing-relaysrv` packages do not include the systemd `.service` files anymore, anyone who updates won't have service files anymore and the services won't be (re)started anymore.

body: This is the correct issue tracker, yes.

rename.to: Include systemd units in stdiscosrv/strelaysrv Debian packages

body:
It _should_ be as simple, as including this files in the build.
These files require a `syncthing` user to be present on the system, is this handled by your packages or do I need to post the control files?
I don't think it is (didn't check). What's wrong with using `syncthing-discosrv@.service` style user definition?
I guess the idea is that these services usually only run once on a given machine, and can do so out of the box under a service account.

Yes that's the idea. I don't think it's a common case that someone wants to run multiple relay/discovery servers on one machine and if so he can simply create copies and can hard code the arguments (That's done via environment files in these service files case).
If you want I can write documented environment files that show how to configure the services (if someone is not familiar with these).

This is what I use to run a public relay, note the hardening part to ensure nothing is writable except home:
```
[Unit]
Description=Syncthing relay server
After=network.target

[Service]
User=syncthing-relaysrv
ExecStart=/usr/bin/strelaysrv -global-rate=1048576
WorkingDirectory=~
Nice=15

# hardening
User=syncthing-relaysrv
PrivateTmp=yes
ReadOnlyPaths=/
ReadWritePaths=/home/syncthing-relaysrv
NoNewPrivileges=true

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
```

I would change 2 things:
- Do not hardcode the options, but include them with `$RELAYSRVOPTS` an environment file like `/etc/defaults/syncthing-relaysrv`
- Do create the user as systemuser with home `/var/lib/syncthing-relaysrv`, because `/home` is for human users

Also we need to the Deb would need 2 things:
- A default file: `/etc/defaults/syncthing-relaysrv`
- Create a system user with home at `/var/lib/syncthing-relaysrv`

Also I don't know if we should hardcode the nice, but a nice of 15 seems reasonable

I don't know how the debs are handled by syncthing, but I might try adding a PR, if I find time for that.

And we might consider making `/home` unreadable for it to protect user data.

Can anybody from the syncthing team tell us, which files the services MUST have read access to and write access to?
I suspect the usual stuff in terms of the config, db and keys the processes use, plus stuff for name resolution and CA certificates possibly.

That means `/usr` read only? Plus some subpath of `/etc`? 

To configure them in systemd I need the path
That depends on how it's run, which I think is not decided as there is no systemd unit already. I suggest you try this out, I don't have the answers ready.
What do you use to generate the debs?

There is metadata on the files to include in the build script:

https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/ff2cde469e3b00259cd9b5ee89a06400bf7efd73/build.go#L124-L168

The actual package build done using the `fpm` tool with the binaries we just built:

https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/ff2cde469e3b00259cd9b5ee89a06400bf7efd73/build.go#L557-L613
In the end this is triggered by something like `go run build.go deb stdiscosrv`
"fpm" is this tool: https://github.com/jordansissel/fpm
I'll look into it
Well it has `--systemd`, `--default` and `--activate`. Where should I store additional files in this repo?
Like the service files

> 
> 
> I would change 2 things:
> 
>     * Do not hardcode the options, but include them with `$RELAYSRVOPTS` an environment file like `/etc/defaults/syncthing-relaysrv`
> 
>     * Do create the user as systemuser with home `/var/lib/syncthing-relaysrv`, because `/home` is for human users
> 
> 
> Also we need to the Deb would need 2 things:
> 
>     * A default file: `/etc/defaults/syncthing-relaysrv`
> 
>     * Create a system user with home at `/var/lib/syncthing-relaysrv`
> 
> 
I agree with all your remarks, I wrote that service file quickly for myself, and I don't think it should be used as such.

The Arch Linux service files for `syncthing-relaysrv` are worth having a look: https://git.archlinux.org/svntogit/community.git/tree/trunk?h=packages/syncthing
The hardening is a bit more relaxed because it uses `ProtectSystem=full` instead of my approach of everything read only + exceptions, but it does create a new user cleanly, and uses /var/lib/syncthing-relaysrv as a directory.
Yes my files are based on the Ubuntu packages, if you need them in the arch files I'm afraid you will need to help me

I am using both Ubuntu and Arch Linux, and I am happy with the Arch systemd files, but they are downstream.
I am just saying maybe they could be reused partially or fully, in the upstream Ubuntu package files.
I just thought we could integrate them into the arch packages as well

Sure, once they are in a Syncthing release, the Arch packager will most likely use them (like they do with the standard syncthing service). We'll remind them if they don't.
Arch has a policy of "minimum change to upstream".
